articles.headline: Janet Yellen Gets a Chance to Shape the Fed, This Time From Outside
articles.snippet: As Jerome H. Powell nears the end of his term as Federal Reserve chair, Ms. Yellen will have a say over whether he should stay on. Many progressive Democrats want him replaced.
articles.abstract: As Jerome H. Powell nears the end of his term as Federal Reserve chair, Ms. Yellen will have a say over whether he should stay on. Many progressive Democrats want him replaced.
articles.lead_paragraph: Janet L. Yellen has dedicated most of her professional life to the Federal Reserve. She served in its highest-ranking roles, including as president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, on its Washington-based board and as the central bank’s first female chair. When President Donald J. Trump decided to replace her in that role in 2017, she was sorely disappointed.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: Haiti Quake Destroyed Many Churches, Shredding a Mainstay of Support
articles.snippet: “We are the only thing here,” said a cleric in Les Cayes, one of the cities worst hit by the quake. In some towns, not a church was left standing.
articles.abstract: “We are the only thing here,” said a cleric in Les Cayes, one of the cities worst hit by the quake. In some towns, not a church was left standing.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — The houses collapsed, the hospitals were damaged, the roads buckled or turned impassable. But it was the earthquake’s destruction of churches across Haiti’s southern peninsula that may prove the biggest gut punch to the roughly 1.5 million people affected.
articles.byline: By Maria Abi-Habib and Andre Paultre

articles.headline: Chaos Ensues at Kabul Airport as Americans Abandon Afghanistan
articles.snippet: Images of desperate Afghans clinging to departing military planes underscored America’s blunders after 20 years in the country.
articles.abstract: Images of desperate Afghans clinging to departing military planes underscored America’s blunders after 20 years in the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Thousands of desperate Afghans trying to escape the Taliban takeover swarmed Kabul’s main international airport on Monday, rushing the boarding gates, mobbing the runways, clambering atop the wings of jets and even trying to cling to the fuselage of departing American military planes.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and Ruhullah Khapalwak

articles.headline: U.S. Veterans View Afghan Collapse With Anguish, Rage and Relief
articles.snippet: “I just can’t help thinking about what a waste it is,” one veteran said. “I can’t allow myself to think about how after all that blood and treasure, it ends like this.”
articles.abstract: “I just can’t help thinking about what a waste it is,” one veteran said. “I can’t allow myself to think about how after all that blood and treasure, it ends like this.”
articles.lead_paragraph: On Javier Mackey’s second deployment to Afghanistan, one of his friends was shot in an ambush and bled to death in his arms. He saw high-ranking Afghan officers selling off equipment for personal gain and Afghan troops running away during firefights. And he started wondering what the United States could really achieve by sending thousands of troops to a distant land that seemed to have never known peace. That was in 2008.

articles.headline: Days May Be Numbered for the World’s Oldest Bank
articles.snippet: After performing poorly in a stress test, Monte dei Paschi di Siena, founded in 1472, could be swallowed by UniCredit.
articles.abstract: After performing poorly in a stress test, Monte dei Paschi di Siena, founded in 1472, could be swallowed by UniCredit.
articles.lead_paragraph: SIENA, Italy — Last month Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena, the world’s oldest bank, acquired another distinction: Europe’s weakest lender.
articles.byline: By Gaia Pianigiani and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: ‘It Happened So Fast’: Inside a Fatal Tesla Autopilot Accident
articles.snippet: A 2019 crash in Florida highlights how gaps in Tesla’s driver-assistance system and distractions can have tragic consequences.
articles.abstract: A 2019 crash in Florida highlights how gaps in Tesla’s driver-assistance system and distractions can have tragic consequences.
articles.lead_paragraph: George Brian McGee, a finance executive in Florida, was driving home in a Tesla Model S operating on Autopilot, a system that can steer, brake and accelerate a car on its own, when he dropped his phone during a call and bent down to look for it.

articles.headline: Retail Sales Fell in July, Highlighting a Rocky Economic Recovery
articles.snippet: The 1.1 percent decline was sharper than economists had expected and came as sales of cars and home goods dropped.
articles.abstract: The 1.1 percent decline was sharper than economists had expected and came as sales of cars and home goods dropped.
articles.lead_paragraph: Retail sales dropped in July, the Commerce Department reported Tuesday, a sign that consumer spending was hampered amid an uneven economic recovery from pandemic-induced restrictions.

articles.headline: When Kmart Moved Out, Churches and Flea Markets Moved In
articles.snippet: The retailer’s former stores are being used by tenants that might not typically get a crack at such a large haul of commercial space at an affordable price.
articles.abstract: The retailer’s former stores are being used by tenants that might not typically get a crack at such a large haul of commercial space at an affordable price.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Kmart opened its first store, in Garden City, Mich., in 1962, the aim was to become an all-under-one-roof retailer. Americans’ shopping habits had gravitated toward the suburbs after World War II, and Kmart was going to cater to them.

articles.headline: For Afghan Women, Taliban Stir Fears of Return to a Repressive Past
articles.snippet: Since the U.S. ousted the Taliban, women and girls have rejoined society in ways that would have been unimaginable under their rule. Now those gains are threatened.
articles.abstract: Since the U.S. ousted the Taliban, women and girls have rejoined society in ways that would have been unimaginable under their rule. Now those gains are threatened.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Afghan women cloistered in their homes on Tuesday, fearing for their lives and their futures under Taliban rule, a pair of female television broadcasters offered starkly contradictory visions of the country’s direction.
articles.byline: By Farnaz Fassihi and Dan Bilefsky

articles.headline: People Now Spend More at Amazon Than at Walmart
articles.snippet: Proof that the online future has arrived: The biggest e-commerce company outside China has unseated the biggest brick-and-mortar seller.
articles.abstract: Proof that the online future has arrived: The biggest e-commerce company outside China has unseated the biggest brick-and-mortar seller.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Amazon has eclipsed Walmart to become the world’s largest retail seller outside China, according to corporate and industry data, a milestone in the shift from brick-and-mortar to online shopping that has changed how people buy everything from Teddy Grahams to teddy bears.
articles.byline: By Karen Weise and Michael Corkery
